shaykh.heading: Supervisor
shaykh.short_bio: Shaykh Abd al-Rahman al-Sha’ar began seeking knowledge at a young age, being nurtured by scholars and those who love knowledge. He dedicated his life to the service of Islam and studied complete curriculums in all its areas, including: Quran, Hadith, Fiqh, Aqida, Tasawwuf, Arabic and its sciences, and more. He received all this divine knowledge at the hands of lordly scholars, attaining full license to teach all the inner and the outer religious sciences from many of the top scholars of the past century. Today, he dedicates himself to producing both books and scholars of the highest standard.
shaykh.long_bio_studies_1: Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān began seeking knowledge and memorizing the noble Qur’an in Masjid al-Ashmar and Masjid Zayd b. Thābit. He then entered Maʿhad al-Fatḥ al-Islāmī and graduated with honors. He would attend the classes of a number of great scholars in Syria, such as Shaykh ʿAbd al-Razzāq al-Ḥalabī’s morning lessons in the Umayyad Mosque, Shaykh Khalīl al-Ṣabbāgh’s lessons in Masjid Ward al-Kabīr, and the erudite Shaykh Usāma al-Rifāʿī’s classes in the Masjid of ʿAbd al-Karīm al-Rifāʿī. He memorized parts of the Qur’an under the tutelage of Shaykh Shukrī al-Luḥafī and Shaykh Muḥammad al-Sayyid Ismāʿīl Abū Munīr.
shaykh.long_bio_studies_2: Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān attended the lessons of Shaykh Muḥammad Jumuʿa for ten years and studied many books with him in various sciences in Maʿhad al-Fatḥ as well as outside of it. Among the books Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān read in Ḥanafī fiqh are: Marāqī al-Falāḥ, al-Ikhtiyār li-Taʿlīl al-Mukhtār, two-thirds of Ḥāshiyat Ibn ʿĀbidīn, some of Sharḥ al-Jaṣṣāṣ ʿalá Mukhtaṣar al-Ṭahāwī, Badā’iʿ al-Ṣanā’iʿ, Sharḥ al-Taṣrīḥ ʿalá al-Tawḍīḥ, and Tafsīr al-Nasafī. Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān also read al-Aṣl: Mabsūṭ al-Imām Muḥammad and al-Lubāb: Sharḥ al-Kitāb by himself and reviewed more difficult passages with Shaykh Muḥammad Jumuʿa.
shaykh.long_bio_studies_3: He attended the lessons of Shaykh Muḥammad Shuqayr in Masjid al-Ḥasan and studied many works with him, such as al-Risāla al-Qushayriyya, Sunan Abī Dāwūd, al-Jāmiʿ by al-Tirmidhī, Sharḥ Ibn ʿAqīl, al-Nahw al-Wāḍiḥ, Iḥyā’ ʿUlūm al-Dīn, al-Adhkār, and Sharḥ al-Nawawī ʿalá Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim. Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān attended the lessons of the erudite scholar Shaykh Muḥammad Abū al-Hudá al-Yaʿqūbī, studying with him Sharḥ Umm al-Barāhīn by al-Sanūsī in the Umayyad Mosque and Qawā’id al-Taṣawwuf in the Masjid of Muḥyī al-Dīn b. al-ʿArabī. He attended the lessons of Shaykh Muḥammad Asʿad al-Ṣāgharjī, reading with him Sharḥ al-Mabāḥith al-Aṣliyya by ibn ʿAjība and al-Fatḥ al-Rabbāni by Shaykh ʿAbd al-Qādir al-Jīlānī. He also attended the lessons of Shaykh Ḥassān al-Hindī, read with him at Maʿhad al-Fatḥ and after graduating, and benefitted greatly from him. He read Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī with Shaykh Naʿīm ʿAraqsūsī. Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān attended the gatherings of ḥadīth held by Shaykh ʿUmar Nashūqātī in Masjid al-Ḥājibiyya, studied other sciences, and read several books with him, including al-Adab al-Mufrad by al-Bukhārī, al-Muwaṭṭa’ by Imam Mālik, al-Āthār by Imam Muḥammad, and the Shamā’il of Imam al-Tirmidhī.
shaykh.long_bio_spirituality_1: Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān grew up under the nurturing wing of Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān al-Shāghūrī as his father took him to the public and private lessons of the shaykh. Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān adored Shaykh al-Shāghūrī from a young age; the latter would consistently go out of his way for Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān until God took back Shaykh al-Shāghūrī’s soul in 2004, when Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān was only eighteen years old. Consequently, Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān continued the path of taṣawwuf under the guidance of Shaykh Muṣṭafá al-Turkmānī, consistently attending and recording his lessons for seven years until the shaykh’s passing. Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān then completed the path under the guidance of Shaykh Shukrī al-Luḥafī; upon his instruction, Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān entered spiritual seclusion (khalwa). He was also the head singer at Shaykh Shukrī’s public and private gatherings, accompanying him for several years.
shaykh.long_bio_spirituality_2: Afterwards, Shaykh Muḥammad Amīn al-Fārūqī requested that Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān enter spiritual seclusion under him; thereafter, he specially authorized Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān in the path to give spiritual guidance, enter others into spiritual seclusions, and prescribe the Singular Name [i.e., a spiritual practice involving repetition of the name ‘Allāh’].
shaykh.long_bio_spirituality_3: Shaykh ʿAbd al-Raḥmān then entered another spiritual seclusion under Shaykh ʿAbd al-Bāqī Miftāḥ al-Jazā’irī, who also authorized him in the path, and then with Shaykh Ḥasan al-Anṣārī al-Jazā’irī, who would authorize him as well. Among the greats he benefitted most from in the arena of experiential Sufism was Shaykh Kamāl al-Ḥusaynī al-Shamīsātī, one of the students of Shaykh Muḥammad al-Hāshimī.

goals.1: Spreading the inner and outer sciences as Imam al-Ghazali accomplished – Allah be pleased with him.
goals.2: Perfecting the reading of the Noble Quran in recitation and tajwid, with a linked chain of ascription and ijaza certification in the Ten Readings – all upon the way the noble Companions received the Quran from the Prophet – peace and blessings upon him –along with reviving the role of the Quran in Muslims’ souls.
goals.3: Reviving the service of the Prophetic Sunnah and the noble Science of Hadith in both narration and understanding. Furthermore, resetting the compass of the Ummah towards following the guidance of the Prophet – Allah send peace and blessings upon him – and also his biography (Sirah), so that the Ummah can gain peace and be saved.
goals.4: Explaining the obligatory knowledge every Muslim man and woman must know—for a slave of Allah to worship his Lord upon based guidance and be free of sins based on his ignorance of that.
goals.5: Teaching the correct beliefs of the righteous predecessors (Salaf). This is done through the Sunni method as demonstrated in the beliefs of the Ashʿari, Maturidi, and Athar approaches, along with the understanding of the lordly scholars and knowers of the Ummah.
goals.6: Explaining the detailed rulings of the Divine law of Allah (Shariʿa) in accordance with the Four Imams – Allah be pleased upon them. Thus, a Muslim can apply his religion correctly in accordance with the pure Sharia, and his actions can be built upon Fiqh and sound knowledge, allowing one to worship Allah Almighty based upon guidance and leave the prison of ignorance and the forbidden.
goals.7: Spreading the correct spirituality (tasawwuf) which is the soul of the religion, what’s been named ihsan. This includes both spiritual seeking and enlightened understanding. This is for a Muslim to leave all sins and follow the way of the Master of All Creation in worshipping His lord with witnessing and awareness that he himself is being witnessed, which leads to complete inheritance and following.
goals.8: Teaching the Arabic language, the language of the Quan and the Beloved Prophet – peace and blessings upon him. This is to correctly understand the words of Allah Almighty and the purified prophetic Sunnah, and the words of the scholars. Indeed, it has been said: “Whoever does not perfect the Arabic language, is not trusted in his knowledge.”
goals.9: Perfecting the tool-sciences such as rhetoric (maʿani), expression (bayan), linguistic devices (badiʿ), etymology (sarf), grammar (nahw), poetic meters, and logic. A student of knowledge needs all of them in order to completely absorb knowledge and then present it in the best way possible.
goals.10: Training in dawah, public speaking and poetry skills, all of which are essential in benefitting others, through an approach where one can express things in a clear, convincing, and moving way.

knowledge_good_intentions.title: Good Intentions – Advice for Students of Knowledge 1
knowledge_good_intentions.content:
ترجمة الوصايا لطالب العلم الوصية الأولى
Advice for Students of Knowledge
Advice 1: Good Intentions
The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said, “Actions are only by intention, and for every man is only what he intended.”
The first obligation upon a student of knowledge is to make a good intention for his knowledge and teaching. A good, sincere intention is the greatest of elixirs — the good and benefit of an action is multiplied in accordance with the plentitude of intentions.
Some the intentions that a student of knowledge should have are the following:
- Preservation of the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him
- Obedience to the command of the Beloved, peace and blessings be upon him
- Listening to and transmitting the speech of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him
- Lifting sins from oneself and fellow Muslims by learning and teaching the personal and communal obligations
- Exposure to the winds of Divine Mercy in order to attain His pleasure
- Remembrance and reminder
- Preserving one’s time 
- Spreading the sacred teachings of Islam 
- I`tikāf (religious seclusion) if the gathering is in the mosque 
- Renewal of faith
- Mutual assistance to piety,  mindfulness of God, commanding the good, and forbidding the evil
- Increasing the collective body of the people of good 
- Seeking the mercy of Allah to descend by remembering the righteous
- Purification of the inward and struggling against the lower self
- Acting according to one’s knowledge Oh Allah, make our knowledge, actions, teaching, and the rest of our actions sincere for Your Noble Countenance, by the rank of Your Greatest Beloved, peace and blessings be upon him and his beloveds.
 A servant of this noble knowledge,
Abd al-Rahman al-Sha`ār
02/21/19

tags.fard_explanation: The Prophet said - Allah bless him and send him peace: "Seeking knowledge is mandatory upon every Muslim." The Scholars have explained that this obligatory knowledge on every Muslim man and women are five: Beliefs, Tajwid to correct what is recited in Salah, Fiqh of Worship & Interactions, and Purification of the soul.
tags.aqidah_explanation: Truly, Beliefs is the most noble religious science. It is the bedrock of all obligations, and the foundation of all commands—because it is linked to the Divine Being. This is why it's mandatory for every Muslim to learn what will correct his beliefs, as Allah Almighty said: "And I have not created jinn or human beings except to worship Me." [51:56] Ibn Jurayj explained: "That means: 'To know Me.'"
tags.sirah_explanation: Works of Prophetic Biography & Description give out rays of light, the light of Islamic principles and lofty ettiqutte. It is what allows one to udnerstand the book of Allah Almighty and its goals. Surely the Prophet (peace and blessings upon him) is the practical example of all that is in the Quran, as Lady Aisha (Allah be pleased upon her) said: 'His ettiquette was the Quran.'
tags.natiq_explanation: After learning the knowledge obligatory upon every Muslim, learning Arabic for non-Arabs is a life-changing improvement, allowing them to understand the Quran, Sunnah, and Scholars directly without any barrier.
tags.tajwid_explanation: Truly the science of Tajwid is part of the knowledge obligatory for every Muslim to learn – to the extent by which Salah is valid. The goal of Tajwid is giving the Quran and each letter in it its right, and to recite as the Prophet (peace and blessings upon him) recited.
tags.arabi_explanation: "Indeed Allah Almighty honored the Arabic language out of all others, by making it the vessel for His Noble Book and the Sunnah of His Prophet - Allah send blessings and peace upon him - the Almighty said: "We have sent it down as an Arabic Quran so that you may understand" [Yusuf: 2]. Thus, it is the tongue of the clear Divine law and it's study is widespread and an inseparable part of the religion."
tags.fiqh_explanation: Truly Fiqh is one of the noblest and greatest religious sciences - after learning what corrects his belief. Indeed, Fiqh corrects a person's worship and interactions, allowing him to worship Allah upon guidance, getting to know Him in the worldy life upto the levels of the rigtheous, and in the afterlife upto the ranks of the best. Allah make us of them by His generosity and favor!
tags.tasawwuf_explanation: There is no doubt that Tasawwuf (Spirituality) is the most beneficial knowledge, because it is the way to clear the soul of its flaws and filth, and adorning it with higher truths and realities, and purifying it with precise and wonderful details. Thus it is the beneficial knowledge the fruit of which is fear of Allah Almighty. Real Spirituality is what makes clear the behavioural, nurturing and development method - and after that the spiritual. It is made up of three stages: cleansing, adorning and manifesting.
tags.tafsir_explanation: "Truly the Quran is the book of guidance for mankind, it guides them to the upright, and leads them to what is good for their worldly- and afterlife. Among the most important things a Muslim must be concerned about and focus on: reflecting on the Quran and understanding its meanings. That is the way to success in this life and the next, and this is not possible except by returning to what the Scholars of Tafsir have written about the Words of Allah Almighty."
tags.hadith_explanation: Surely the Prophetic Sunnah is the source of Islam and reviver of Iman in the hearts. Whoever reads these noble hadith is in the company of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings upon him), receiving knowledge and insight from him. And truly the scholars of Islam have precisely preserved all these narrations with the utmost excellence and clarity.
